thread.title: Paul Smith of Maximo Park revels in home crowd and on stage patter on solo tour

author: Simon Meechan
title: Paul Smith of Maximo Park revels in home crowd and on stage patter on solo tour
text:
What's On opinion Paul Smith of Maximo Park revels in home crowd and on stage patter on solo tour Maximo Park's frontman has three solo albums to his name, his solo project allows him to play guitar on stage and engage in more audience interaction Share Get what's on updates
Maximo Park's Paul Smith is famed for his energy, a frontman who treats the stage like a personal dancefloor.
That's no bad thing, but in Maximo, Paul doesn't get to play guitar, so has no instrument weighing him down.
However, in his solo work, Paul plays guitar on stage. This allows him extra creative input, and - with less room for manoeuvre in the mid-air splits department - there is more energy to spend on patter between songs. This freedom, Paul told the Glasgow Evening Times , is something he enjoys, with audience interaction occasionally meaning his shows run longer than intended.
On home turf at Newcastle's Cluny , Paul spoke to the crowd like an old friend. They responded likewise. Hardly surprising, given how embedded he is in the North East music scene, one which he proudly represents.
The Teesside native and Tyneside resident was on form on Saturday night.
Opener Public Eye, taken from new album Diagrams, feels very apt, given its lyrics about the current 'hostile climate' against marginalised groups, which led to events like the Windrush scandal. It was a worthy kick-start.
The political and cultural climate was a theme throughout, sprinkled with tales and scenes from living in the North East and travelling further afield, something the observant Smith has long been adept at. A Billingham letterbox is referenced in Crush and the Shatter, while Around and Around focuses on the never ending news cycle as Brexit approaches Britain.
The set took us through Paul's three albums: Margins, Contradictions and Diagrams, with changes in tempo and style anyone familiar with Maximo Park would recognise.
That tempo dropped for the melodic Lake Burley Griffin, while Paul picked it up again for Syrian Plains.
The main set closed on the more punky Silver Rabbit, again showing Paul can take a crowd through a range of styles, before an encore featuring two Maximo Park songs.
If you're keen to catch Paul play live, he is due to perform at Gosforth Civic Theatre on Monday, December 3. However, the daytime show is for adults with babies who are aged 18 months and younger. So if you missed Saturday's gig as you couldn't get a babysitter, here's your chance!
